body.p:
Dear Sir—More than four weeks ago
I addressed a letter to you, with the request to send me
a copy of your octavo Bible bound in purple velvet, with
gilded clasp &c, designed for a nuptial present, and in-
close my bill the amount of which I do not know. The
wedding took place yesterday, and I have not yet received
the Bible, although I wrote that I wanted it in the first
week of September. As it is, I would be glad, to receive
it at least before Hebrew. It is to be presented to Mrs.
Sarah I. Davega, formerly Mrs. I. J. Moses, sister to my wife.
What say to this news? No doubt, you heard of this “match”
before, considering that you are generally an courant with
all that transpires at least amongst the Israelites of Charles-
ton.

But, have you been informed also of the
discussion which has been carried on, for the last weeks, on
the subject of the Swiss Treaty, in the Courier of this city? Have
you been informed that, after I had published an Article, on
the 13th of August last, calling upon the Jews of Charleston, “to
act now in concert, and forget all differences of religious opinion,” and appealing to the Press for assistance, “A Jew” appeared
in the same paper charging me with “either ignorance
or hasty and impetuous zeal,” and cautioning the Jews against
being aroused to action, since by that treaty “their rights, as Americans

are not assailed, and their religious privilege in no way molested”? I
replied, sustaining my position, and declared at the conclusion that
I should no farther notice any “anonymous” communication. Yet, “A Jew”
again came forth, defending the treaty, repeating the charge of my ignorance,
and calling all that had as yet been written on the subject by
Editors “flimsy remarks.” In reply to him, Mr. J. N. Cardoza
entered the arena in a most gentlemanly and quiet Article.
To this “A Jew” replied in a most scurrilous and insulting
Article, without even once coming to the point at issue, nay! he was
even so ungenerous & uncharitable, not to say ungentlemanly, to cast
some open flings at me, although I had withdrawn from the controversy
and thus placed myself beyond the possibility of defence.

Now Mr. N. published an Article, containing a most withering
lesson for the unavoidable position which “A Jew” had taken in this affair.
The latter took offence at this and published a card, demanding
an explanation from Mr. C. This was not given, and so there
was for the last 3 days a fine prospect of a duel. Things,
however, I think, are now settled. You yourself were drawn
into this controversy. In his first Article, Mr. C. quoted from
the Occident, Vol. XII, p. 95-100, to prove that you had then already
written against the Treaty as it now stands; “A Jew” denied
this fact, in his reply, maintaining that you meant the original draft
containing the word “Christian,” and to prove this, he quoted
from Vol. 15, March '51!!! Is this not very fair, after Mr C. had
quoted your very words and which could certainly not be found in the
March Number of 1851!? What must “A Jew” now think of
this incidental point, after having read your Article on the
Swiss Treaty, in which you refer to the very pages quoted
by Mr. C.? Has your usual informant or reporter not com-

municated all this to you? If he has, did he give you also the
name of “A Jew.”? At all events, I will give it to you. It is
Mr. Charles H. Moise. I do not envy him for the laurels which
he has won in this warfare; all he gained is this, that the Press of S. C.
become lukewarm & indifferent, after some papers had taken
up our cause. Nevertheless, a memorial will be sent to the President
by Jews, if not the Jews of Charleston; it is now being circulated
for subscription. Will you expose this extraordinary proceeding of a
Jew in this affair? Justice demands it!

I read your Article on the New Prayer-book “Minhag
America,” in the last month's Occidents. I agree fully with you
concerning the transgression of power by the Compilers; I wrote
the same truths to Dr Cohn in Albany already two months
ago, that is, before you published your strictures. I think the
very title is a piece of presumption and usurpation which
cannot be justified save by means of vulgar abuse and
contemptible insults.

Now an open and honest explanation; I received your
invitation to the Consecration of your Synagogue. I did not
answer, nor attend. Why? Because I endorse every word contained
in the Editorial of the Asmonean, of May 9. last, and referring
to the establishment of your congregation.

With my wife's and my own best regard, and our wishes
for the coming New-Year, I remain, as ever,
P.S. What is Mr. S. Jacobs doing? Is it
true, that he has been appointed Professor of
the Hebrew, at the Girard College, with a salary
of $2000 a year? So Mr A. H. Abrahams tells the people here.
What is is salary as Lecturer? Did you ever here the particulars of his resignation?
